message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The CT scan of the head shows ventricular dilation and narrowing of the sulci, which is indicative of this condition. Parkinson’s disease would have tremors and bradykinesia, but the patient has stiff movement and postural instability, which suggests a gait disturbance rather than Parkinson’s disease. Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease would have different symptoms such as difficulty with speech and mood changes. Progressive supranuclear palsy would have vertical gaze palsy and rapid onset, whereas Normal-pressure hydrocephalus has a gradual onset.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan shows ventriculomegaly, which suggests Normal-pressure hydrocephalus as the most likely diagnosis. Parkinson's disease and Progressive supranuclear palsy would show more significant motor symptoms, and Early-onset Alzheimer's disease would not show ventriculomegaly. The patient's gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and memory problems also support the diagnosis of Normal-pressure hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus. He has urinary incontinence and difficulty walking, which are characteristic features of the disease. The CT scan of the head also shows ventriculomegaly, which is a common finding in normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy usually present with tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia, which are not present in this patient. Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease may also present with memory problems but is not associated with urinary incontinence and difficulty walking.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus, including difficulty in remembering things, urinary incontinence, and slow gait with small steps. The CT scan also confirms ventriculomegaly. Alzheimer’s disease usually affects memory and cognition while leaving gait intact. Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy both involve abnormal muscle tone and rigidity, which are not seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with memory loss, urinary incontinence, and gait disturbances. The CT scan shows ventricular enlargement, which is indicative of normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The other options do not present with these symptoms and CT findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows ventriculomegaly, which is consistent with normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The patient’s symptoms (memory problems, urinary incontinence, shuffling gait) are also indicative of this condition. Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease would exhibit more severe cognitive impairments, while Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy would present with more prominent movement disorders. The absent Romberg’s sign is supportive of normal-pressure hydrocephalus as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan shows enlarged ventricles, which is a classic finding in normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The patient’s symptoms also fit with this diagnosis, including memory problems, urinary incontinence, and difficulty with gait and balance. Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy would typically present with other symptoms, such as tremors or rigidity. Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease would be a possibility, but the CT scan findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan image shows enlarged ventricles, which is a characteristic finding of normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The symptoms, including memory problems, urinary problems, and gait disturbance, also support this diagnosis as they are commonly seen in patients with normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Parkinson's disease and progressive supranuclear palsy generally do not present with urinary problems. Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease may present with memory problems, but it is not usually associated with gait changes and urinary symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of memory problems, urinary incontinence, and difficulty walking suggest the most likely diagnosis is normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The CT scan shows enlarged ventricles, which is a characteristic finding in normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Other options have different characteristic findings on imaging or different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with normal-pressure hydrocephalus, including memory problems, urinary incontinence, and gait abnormalities. The CT scan of the head also shows enlarged ventricles, which is a hallmark of normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease typically presents with solely cognitive symptoms and is unlikely given the gait abnormalities. Parkinson’s disease typically presents with tremors and rigidity, which the patient did not exhibit. Progressive supranuclear palsy typically presents with early falls and vertical gaze difficulties, which were not seen in this patient.
